title: Team Project
section: 1 US county map of climate change belief in 2018
text:
1 US county map of climate change belief in 2018
  Estimated percentage who think that global warming is caused mostly by human activities

cc_belief_county <- read_csv(
  'https://bcdanl.github.io/data/cc_belief_county.csv'
)


legend_title <- ""

ggplot(data = cc_belief_county) +
  geom_polygon(aes(long, lat, group = group, 
                   fill = human2018),
               color = "grey", size = 0.1) +
  coord_map("bonne", parameters = 41.6) + 
  scale_fill_gradient(legend_title, 
                      low='#0057e7', 
                      high='#d62d20') +
  theme_map() + 
  theme(legend.position="right") +
  labs(caption = "Data source: Yale Climate Change Communication")

title: Data Cleaning Econ399
text:
R_Data_Econ399 <- read_excel("C:\\Users\\Devon DiMatteo\\Documents\\R Data Econ399.xlsx")
View(R_Data_Econ399)


df <- R_Data_Econ399 
df_1 <- df[, 1:2]
df_2 <- df[, 3:4]
df_3 <- df[, 5:6]
df_4 <- df[, 7:8]
df_5 <- df[, 9:10]
df_6 <- df[, 11:12]
df_7 <- df[, 13:14]
df_8 <- df[, 15:16]
df_9 <- df[, 17:18]
df_10 <- df[, 19:20]
df_11 <- df[, 21:22]

df_1$type <- colnames(df)[2]
df_2$type <- colnames(df)[4]
df_3$type <- colnames(df)[6]
df_4$type <- colnames(df)[8]
df_5$type <- colnames(df)[10]
df_6$type <- colnames(df)[12]
df_7$type <- colnames(df)[14]
df_8$type <- colnames(df)[16]
df_9$type <- colnames(df)[18]
df_10$type <- colnames(df)[20]
df_11$type <- colnames(df)[22]

colnames(df_1) <- c('country', 'value', 'type')
colnames(df_2) <- c('country', 'value', 'type')
colnames(df_3) <- c('country', 'value', 'type')
colnames(df_4) <- c('country', 'value', 'type')
colnames(df_5) <- c('country', 'value', 'type')
colnames(df_6) <- c('country', 'value', 'type')
colnames(df_7) <- c('country', 'value', 'type')
colnames(df_8) <- c('country', 'value', 'type')
colnames(df_9) <- c('country', 'value', 'type')
colnames(df_10) <- c('country', 'value', 'type')
colnames(df_11) <- c('country', 'value', 'type')

df_full <- rbind(df_1, df_2, df_3, df_4, df_5, 
                 df_6, df_7, df_8, df_9, df_10, df_11) %>% 
  arrange(country, type)

df_full_sum <- df_full %>% 
  group_by(country, type) %>% 
  count() %>% 
  arrange(-n)



df_wide <- df_full %>% 
  filter(!is.na(country)) %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = type,
              values_from = value,
              values_fill = NA)


#df_final <- df_wide
#write_csv(df_final, "C:\\Users\\Devon DiMatteo\\Documents\\df_wide.csv")


summary(df_wide)

title: NCAA Basketball Regression
text:
Introduction

Why does your research project matter
Motive for project
Summarize the project in the last paragraph



Data

Summary statistics (Use skimr::skim())



Conceptual Framework

Justify your ML model.
Why the model considers the variables in the model.



Model

Add some model equation

Empirical Model:
\[y_{i} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}ADJOE + \beta_{2}ADJDE + \beta_{3}EFG_O + \beta_{4}{EFG\_D}_{i} + \beta_{5}TOR_{i} + \beta_{6}TORD_{i} + \beta_{7}2{P\_O}_{i} + \beta_{8}2{P\_D}_{i} + \beta_{9}3{P\_O}_{i} + \beta_{10}SEED_{i} + \beta_{11}WAB_{i} +  \epsilon_{i}\]
\[y_{i} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}X_{i} + \beta_{2}X_{2i} +  \epsilon_{i}\] ##Creating the model in Python


Code
library(readxl)


Warning: package 'readxl' was built under R version 4.2.3


Code
df <- read_excel("C:\\Users\\Devon DiMatteo\\Desktop\\danl310df.xlsx")




Code
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import statsmodels.api as sm


The packages that are used to create the model are numpy, pandas, and statsmodels.apu The first step in the code is to pull the variables that will be used in the regression.


Code
data=pd.read_excel("C:\\Users\\Devon DiMatteo\\Desktop\\danl310df.xlsx")
cbb_data=data.copy()
cbb = cbb_data[[ "W", "ADJOE", "ADJDE", "EFG_O", "EFG_D", "TOR", "TORD", "2P_O","2P_D", "3P_O","3P_D", "SEED", "WAB" ]]
cbb


     W  ADJOE  ADJDE  EFG_O  EFG_D   TOR  ...  2P_O  2P_D  3P_O  3P_D  SEED   WAB

1   31  118.9   90.2   54.9   44.9  17.2  ...  55.0  42.1  36.5  32.9     1   7.6

4   25  107.6   85.0   51.1   43.0  20.1  ...  50.2  41.4  35.3  30.7     2   6.6

65  20  108.1  111.2   54.4   52.6  20.3  ...  53.1  51.1  38.0  37.2    16  -8.6

67  12  100.1  109.7   48.5   47.8  19.8  ...  44.9  48.6  37.0  30.9    16 -15.6

[68 rows x 13 columns]


Next we split the features and the labels into different datasets using the .drop function


Code
cbb_features=cbb.drop("SEED", axis="columns")
cbb_labels=cbb["SEED"]


###Linear Regression Model
For the linear regression model we use scikit-learn software to run the machine learning model.


Code
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
lin_reg=LinearRegression()
lin_reg.fit(cbb_features, cbb_labels)


LinearRegression()


###Decision Tree Model
We also use the scikit-learn software for the dicision tree regression
The following code is training the model:


Code
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeRegressor
tree_reg=DecisionTreeRegressor()
tree_reg.fit(cbb_features, cbb_labels)


DecisionTreeRegressor()




Code
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error
cbb_predictions2=tree_reg.predict(cbb_features)
tree_mse=mean_squared_error(cbb_labels, cbb_predictions2)

import numpy as np
tree_rmse=np.sqrt(tree_mse)

print(tree_rmse)


0.0




Results

Linear Regression Coefficents


Code
lin_reg.coef_


array([-0.05422349, -0.16885729,  0.12692155, -0.97481597, -2.58337805,
        0.01646713, -0.01012986,  0.74896638,  1.85055441,  0.53721335,
        1.42533091, -0.54543421])




Linear Regression p-values


Code
X = sm.add_constant(cbb_features)  # add a constant term to the independent variables
results = sm.OLS(cbb_labels, cbb_features).fit()
p_values = results.pvalues

# print the coefficients and p-values
print("Coefficients:", lin_reg.coef_)


Coefficients: [-0.05422349 -0.16885729  0.12692155 -0.97481597 -2.58337805  0.01646713
 -0.01012986  0.74896638  1.85055441  0.53721335  1.42533091 -0.54543421]

pridected outcomes

You can make suggestions for strategy



Conclusion

title: Homework 2
text:
#2A
hdi_corruption <- read_csv(
  'https://bcdanl.github.io/data/hdi_corruption.csv')
df1 <- hdi_corruption %>% 
  group_by(region)
p1 <- ggplot(data = df1, aes(y = hdi, x = cpi), color = region)+
  geom_point()+
  labs(x = "Corruption Perception Index, 2014 (100 = least corrupt)", 
       y = "Human Development Index, 2014 (1.0 = most developed")
p1 + geom_smooth()



p1





#2B

# library(readr)
labor_supply <- read_csv("C:/Users/Devon DiMatteo/Downloads/labor_supply (1).zip")
df <- labor_supply %>% 
  group_by(YEAR) %>% 
  mutate(pop = sum(ASECWT)) %>% 
  mutate(child = ifelse(NCHLT5 < 5, "Having a Child Under Age 5 in Household"
                        , "No Child Under Age 5 in Highschool"))
  
p2 <- ggplot(data = df, aes(y = pop, x = YEAR))+
  geom_line()+
  facet_wrap(child ~ .)+
  labs(y = "Labor Force Participation Rate")
p2





#2C
#install.packages("ggcorrplot")
library(ggcorrplot) # to create correlation heatmaps using ggcorrplot()

beer_mkt <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/beer_markets.csv')

beer_dummies <- beer_mkt %>% select(-hh, -market) 
reg <- lm(data = beer_dummies,
          beer_floz ~ .)
beer_dummies <-  as.data.frame(model.matrix(reg))[, -1]
beer_dummies <- cbind(beer_mkt$beer_floz ,beer_dummies)
beer_dummies <- beer_dummies %>% 
  rename(beer_floz = `beer_mkt$beer_floz`)

correlation <- as.data.frame(cor(beer_dummies))

#NY markets are
#ALBANY, BUFFALO-ROCHESTER, RURAL NEW YORK, URBAN NY, 
#SUBURBAN NY, EXURBAN NY, SYRACUSE


p3 <- ggcorrplot(correlation)
p3

title: DANL 310: Data Visualization and Presentation Midterm Exam
text:
